findings.title: Skill does not specify a license
findings.description: Skill manifest does not include a 'license' field. Specifying a license helps users understand usage terms.
findings.remediation: Add 'license' field to SKILL.md frontmatter (e.g., MIT, Apache-2.0)

findings.title: Missing allowed-tools Declaration
findings.description: The skill manifest does not specify the 'allowed-tools' field. While this field is optional per the agent skills specification, its absence means there are no declared restrictions on which agent tools can be used. For a skill that makes external API calls, explicitly declaring allowed tools (e.g., [Bash]) would improve transparency and security posture.
findings.remediation: Add 'allowed-tools: [Bash]' to the YAML frontmatter to explicitly declare that this skill requires Bash execution capabilities for making API calls.

metadata.overall_assessment: This YouTube search skill is SAFE for use. It provides a straightforward wrapper around the TranscriptAPI.com service for searching YouTube videos and channels. The skill follows security best practices: it uses environment variables for API key storage (not hardcoded secrets), makes legitimate API calls to a documented third-party service, contains no executable scripts that could perform malicious actions, and has no prompt injection attempts in its instructions. The skill's behavior matches its description accurately. The only findings are minor documentation improvements (missing optional metadata fields) that do not represent security threats. The skill operates as a pure API integration tool with appropriate authentication handling.

findings.title: API Key Required in Environment Variable
findings.description: The skill requires TRANSCRIPT_API_KEY to be stored in the user's environment (~/.zshenv). While this is a standard practice for API authentication, users should be aware that this key will be accessible to any process running in their shell environment. The skill correctly uses environment variable storage rather than hardcoding secrets, which is the proper approach.
findings.remediation: This is actually proper security practice (using environment variables instead of hardcoded secrets). No remediation needed, but users should ensure their API key has appropriate rate limits and monitor usage via the TranscriptAPI dashboard.

findings.title: Missing License and Compatibility Metadata
findings.description: The skill manifest does not specify 'license' or 'compatibility' fields. While these are optional metadata fields, their absence reduces transparency about usage rights and which environments the skill is designed for. This is a documentation quality issue rather than a security threat.
findings.snippet: license: Not specified, compatibility: Not specified
findings.remediation: Add 'license: MIT' (or appropriate license) and 'compatibility: Works in Claude.ai, Claude Code, API' to improve skill metadata completeness.
